facts.text: Appellant employed as Assistant Store keeper in Central Tractor Organisation at Delhi; duty included taking delivery of consignments received by rail.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was employed as an Assistant Store keeper in the Central Tractor Organisation at Delhi and amongst other duties his duty was the taking of delivery of consignment of goods

facts.text: Misappropriation alleged of major portion of wagon load of iron and steel weighing about 500 Mds. received under Railway Receipt No. 039967 dated August 12, 1950 from Tata Iron Steel Co., Tatanagar at Delhi Railway Station.

anchor.surface_text: and in that capacity he is alleged to have misappropriated a major portion of a wagon load of iron and steel weighing about 500 Mds. received at Delhi Railway Station from the Tata Iron

facts.text: Consignment taken delivery of on October 2, 1950 at Lahori Gate Depot.

anchor.surface_text: Steel Co., Tatanagar, under Railway Receipt No. 039967 dated August 12, 1950. This consignment of goods was taken delivery of on October 2, 1950 at the Lahori Gate Depot.

facts.text: Paid Rs. 2,332-4-0 for demurrage on October 2, 1950 by credit notes P.N. and P.O.; further Rs. 57-3-0 on October 3 by credit note P.Q.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant paid Rs. 2,332-4-0 for demurrage by means of credit notes P. N. and P. O. on October 2, and on the following day he paid a further sum of Rs. 57-3-0 by a credit note P. Q.

facts.text: Consignment never reached Central Tractor Organisation; appellant removed and misappropriated the goods.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that this consignment never reached the Central Tractor Organisation and that the appellant had removed these goods and had misappropriated them.

facts.text: Appellant absent from work after October 4, 1950 on ground of illness; sent for on October 7, 1950 and appeared before Director of Administration Mr. F.C. Gera.

anchor.surface_text: He was absent from work after October 4, 1950, on the alleged ground of illness but he was sent for on October 7, and appeared before the Director of Administration Mr. F. C. Gera

facts.text: Appellant explained to Mr. F.C. Gera that he lost the Railway Receipt along with another RR and blank credit notes signed by Petrol and Transport Officer; stated he did not know goods were cleared.

anchor.surface_text: and he gave an explanation that he (the appellant) had lost the Railway Receipt along with another Railway Receipt and blank credit notes which had been signed by the Petrol and Transport Officer.

facts.text: Appellant handed over to police; case registered at instance of Mr. F.C. Gera on October 7, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: After this explanation the appellant was handed over to the police and a case was registered against him at the instance of Mr. C. Gera on October 7, 1950.

facts.text: On October 8, 1950, appellant stated to Sub-Inspector Sumer Shah Singh that he gave goods to Gurbachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On the following day, that is, October 8, 1950, the appellant made a statement to Sub-Inspector Sumer Shah Singh that he had given the goods to Gurbachan Singh who was traced

facts.text: Gurbachan Singh handed over Rs. 200 to appellant in presence of SI (not in uniform); SI took possession.

anchor.surface_text: and in the presence of this Sub-Inspector who was not in uniform at the time Gurbachan Singh handed over Rs. 200 to the appellant which the Sub-Inspector took possession of

facts.text: Gurbachan Singh took party (SI, Dharam Vir, Kartar Singh) to premises of Amar Singh at Kotia Khan; iron and steel goods seized, recovery memos prepared.

anchor.surface_text: and then Gurbachan Singh took the party which consisted of the Sub- Inspector, Dharam Vir of the Central Tractor Organisation and witness Kartar Singh to the premises, of Amar Singh

facts.text: Seven packages of the consignment later recovered from Lahori Gate Goods Depot.

anchor.surface_text: Of the goods covered by the consignment seven packages were later recovered from the Lahori Gate Goods Depot.

facts.text: Defence: Took delivery Oct 2-3, removed to Saloon Siding using CTO truck driven by Sukhdev Singh and carts; produced Sukhdev Singh and two chowkidars.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that he took delivery of the goods on October 2 and 3 and removed them to another Railway Siding known as Saloon Siding where the goods

facts.text: High Court did not accept defence evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has not accepted this evidence.

facts.text: Goods removed from Lahori Gate Depot but not proved to have reached Saloon Siding or Central Tractor Organisation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the position comes to this that the goods received in that consignment were, according to the appellants own showing, removed from the Lahori Gate Depot but it is not

facts.text: Appellant gave false explanation on October 7, 1950 about Railway Receipt and credit notes.

anchor.surface_text: There is also the fact that the appellant gave false explanation on October 7, 1950, as to what had happened to the Railway Receipt or the credit notes

facts.text: Appellant absent from duty October 4 to 7, 1950 until sent for by Mr. F.C. Gera.

anchor.surface_text: and there is the further fact that the appellant was absent from duty from October 4 to October 7 till he was sent for Mr. F.C. Gera.

facts.text: Goods seized from Amar Singh's place do not tally with consignment from Tatanagar; not shown to be Tata Iron Steel Co.'s manufacture.

anchor.surface_text: Now these iron and steel goods do not tally with the goods which were received from Tatanagar under Railway Receipt No. 039967 and the goods seized from Amar Singhs place

facts.text: Appellant took delivery of goods; removed from Lahori Gate Depot; never reached Central Tractor Organisation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the case reduces itself to this that the appellant took delivery of the goods. These goods were removed-from the Lahori Gate Railway Depot by the appellant and they

facts.text: Before High Court, not disputed that appellant took delivery of whole consignment at Lahori Gate and responsible for removal of considerable portions on Oct 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed before the High Court it was not disputed that the appellant took delivery of the whole consignment at Lahori Gate Depot and he was responsible for the actual removal

facts.text: Prosecution failed to connect goods at Amar Singh's with consignment; Gurbachan Singh not produced.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution sought to connect the goods found at Amar Singhs place with the goods received, taken delivery of and removed by the appellant but they failed to do so

arguments.claim: Appellant committed criminal misconduct under s.5(1)(c) PCA by dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriating or converting entrusted property.

anchor.surface_text: The offence of which the appellant has been convicted is s. 5 1   c  of the Act which is as follows- 5.  1  A public servant is said to commit the offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duty  c  if he dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriates or otherwise converts for his own use any property entrusted to him or under his control as a public servant or allows any other person so to do

arguments.claim: Dishonestly means doing anything with intention of causing wrongful gain to one or wrongful loss to another (IPC s.24).

anchor.surface_text: The word dishonestly is defined in s. 24 of the Indian Penal Code to be Whoever does anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person. is said to do that thing dishonestly.

arguments.claim: Fraudulently means doing a thing with intent to defraud (IPC s.25).

anchor.surface_text: Fraudulently has been defined in the Indian Penal Code in s. 25 as follows A person is said to do a thing fraudulently if he does that thing with intent to defraud but, number other-, wise.

arguments.claim: Wrongful gain includes wrongful retention; wrongful loss includes being kept out of property or wrongfully deprived.

anchor.surface_text: Wrongful gain includes wrongful retention and wrongful loss includes being kept out of the property as well as being wrongfully deprived of property.

arguments.claim: In criminal breach of trust, not necessary to prove precise manner of appropriation; dishonest intention key; false account strong evidence.

anchor.surface_text: As was said by Fazl Ali, J., in Harakrishna Mahtab v. Emperor  1  Now I do number mean to suggest that it is either necessary or possible in every case of criminal breach of trust to prove in what precise manner the money was spent or appropriated by the accused because under the law, even temporary retention is an offence, provided that it is dishonest I must point out that the essential thing to be proved in case of criminal breach of trust is whether the accused was actuated by dishonest intention or number.

arguments.claim: s.5(1)(c) same as embezzlement: complete when servant fraudulently misappropriates received property.

anchor.surface_text: The offence under s. 5 1  c  is the same as embezzlement, which in English law, is constituted when the property has been received by the accused for or in the name or on account of the master or employer of the accused and it is complete when the -servant fraudulently misappropriates that property.  Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 10, 3rd Edition, p. 787

arguments.claim: Prosecution not required to eliminate all possible defences if facts within accused's knowledge (s.106 Evidence Act).

anchor.surface_text: it is number enough to establish facts which give rise to a suspicion and then by reason of s. 106 of the Evidence Act to throw the onus on him to prove his innocence. See Harries, C.J., in Emperor v. Santa Singh

arguments.claim: Elements of misappropriation: prosecution proves servant received goods, duty to account, failure to account; accused explains if accidental.

If the failure to account was due to an accidental loss then the facts being within the servants knowledge, it is for him to explain the loss.

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove not only receipt but also conversion to own use and non-application to purpose.

holdings.text: The court would be justified in concluding that the appellant had dishonestly misappropriated the goods of the Central Tractor Organisation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proved receipt of goods by appellant, duty to account, removal from depot, non-delivery to organisation, false explanations given by appellant indicating dishonest intention.

holdings.text: It is not necessary or possible in every case to prove in what precise manner the accused person has dealt with or appropriated the goods of his master.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary or possible in every case to prove in what precise manner the accused person has dealt with or appropriated the goods of his master.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention is key in criminal breach of trust or misappropriation; precise mode not required if dishonest intention shown by circumstances like failure to account.

holdings.text: The prosecution has not to prove that the accused converted the goods to his own use and did not apply them to the purpose for which received; proof of receipt and failure to account suffices with circumstances showing dishonest intention.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's broad contention rejected; cited cases confined to peculiar facts and do not support requiring proof beyond receipt and failure to account.

holdings.text: Giving a false account of what he has done with the goods received by him may be treated as a strong circumstance against the accused person.

anchor.surface_text: The question is one of intention and not a matter of direct proof but giving a false account of what he has done with the goods received by him may be treated a strong circumstance against

holdings.reasoning_summary: False explanation provides evidence of dishonest intention in misappropriation cases, as direct proof of intention unavailable.

holdings.text: It is not the law that the prosecution has to eliminate all possible defences or circumstances which may exonerate the accused; if facts within knowledge of accused, he has to prove them.

anchor.surface_text: It is not the law of this country that the prosecution has to eliminate all possible defences or circumstances which may exonerate him. If these facts are within the knowledge of the accused

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under s.106 Evidence Act, burden shifts to accused for facts specially within his knowledge once prima facie case established; prosecution need not prove negative.

holdings.text: In the case of a servant charged with misappropriating the goods of his master, the elements are established if prosecution proves receipt, duty to account, and failure to account; accused must explain if due to accident.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of a servant charged with misappropriating the goods of his master the elements of criminal offence of misappropriation will be established if the prosecution proves that the servant received the goods, that he was under a duty to account to his master and had not done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies standard test for misappropriation/embezzlement: possession + failure to account raises presumption of dishonest conversion unless rebutted.

holdings.text: The offence under s.5(1)(c) of the Prevention of Corruption Act is the same as embezzlement.

anchor.surface_text: The offence under s. 5 1 c is the same as embezzlement, which in English law, is constituted when the property has been received by the accused for or in the name or on account of the master or employer of the accused and it is complete when the servant fraudulently misappropriates that property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to English law concept where offence completes on fraudulent misappropriation after receipt by servant.

anchor.surface_text: As was said by Fazl Ali, J., in Harakrishna Mahtab v. Emperor 1 Now I do number mean to suggest that it is either necessary or possible in every case of criminal breach of trust to prove in what precise manner the money was spent or appropriated by the accused because under the law, even temporary retention is an offence, provided that it is dishonest I must point out that the essential thing to be proved in case of criminal breach of trust is whether the accused was actuated by dishonest intention or number. As the question of intention is number a matter of direct proof, the Courts have from time to time laid down certain broad tests which would generally afford useful guidance in deciding whether in a particular case the accused had or had number mens area for the crime. So in cases of criminal breach of trust the failure to account for the money proved to have been received by the accused or giving a false account of its use is generally companysidered to be a strong circumstance against the accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: essential thing to be proved in criminal breach of trust is dishonest intention; failure to account or giving false account is strong circumstance against accused
precedents.cited_holding: even temporary retention is an offence, provided that it is dishonest [...] failure to account [...] is generally considered to be a strong circumstance against the accused

anchor.surface_text: Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. 10, 3rd Edition, p. 787 In Larnier v. Rex 2 the offence of embezzlement was A.I. R. 1930 Patna 209. 2 1914 A.C. 221, described as a wilful appropriation by the accused of the property of another. A companyrt of Justice, it was said in that case cannot reach the companyclusion that ,the crime has been companymitted unless it be a just result of the evidence that the accused in what was done or omitted by him was moved by the guilty mind.

precedents.cited_proposition: offence of embezzlement is wilful appropriation of property of another; requires proof of guilty mind

See Harries, C.J., in Emperor v. Santa Singh In the present case the appellant received the companysignment of goods which came from Tatanagar under Railway Receipt No. 039967 and it was found by A.I.R. 1944 Lah. 338 at P. 346.

precedents.cited_proposition: prosecution must establish prima facie case beyond mere suspicion before s.106 Evidence Act shifts onus; accused proves facts in his knowledge

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Chattur Bhuj 1 . In Rex v. William 2 . Again in Reg v. Lynch 3 , Moore, J., said- You have further the fact that, after getting the money, the prisoner absconded and did number companye back till he was in custody. You may infer that he intended to appropriate this money, and if so, he is guilty of embezzlement.
